title: Fortescue hopes Pilbara wind farm will be the 'first of many'
text:
Mining giant Fortescue hopes its new wind farm in Western Australia's Pilbara will be the "first of many" for the region.

The construction of 17 wind turbines for a 133 megawatt farm near Nullagine, 1,360 kilometres north east of Perth, officially began this month as part of Fortescue's plan to offset the emissions from its iron ore production by using renewable energy sources.

The project is expected to be completed in 2027.

Fortescue CEO Dino Otranto said the design of the turbines was a "world first", and he expected the wind farm to be the first of many for the region.

"We need lower-cost electricity to stay competitive, and that is what this [wind farm] does," he said.

However, a renewable energy consultant says while Fortescue is a "best practice leader" in operational decarbonisation, he does not expect an influx of new wind farms in Western Australia's north.

Why wind?

The Pilbara's mining industry is a significant contributor to WA's carbon footprint, accounting for more than 40 per cent of the state's total emissions.

From pit to port, iron ore mining generally involves the use of diesel-powered vehicles like dump trucks, excavators and trains.

Companies across the region's mining sector have begun investing in renewable energy projects to decarbonise — predominantly solar — and in Fortescue's case, to power electric heavy vehicles.

An electric excavator trialled by Fortescue in its move towards transitioning to an electric fleet. (Supplied: Fortescue Metals)

Yet less than 2 per cent of energy generated in the Pilbara is renewable, according to the state government.

Unlike solar, wind in certain areas has the potential to produce energy during the evening.

Mr Otranto said that was why the Nullagine wind farm would complement solar energy.

"What people don't understand is that we have a huge amount of great wind in the Pilbara as well, and the wind actually blows at night or in the late afternoon and early evening," he said.

Dino Otranto says the wind farm's design is a "world first". (Supplied: Fortescue Metals)

" For us it's a no-brainer in the Pilbara. "

The China-made turbines will have an estimated height of 277 metres, making them taller than any others in Australia.

Mr Otranto said taller turbines produced more energy, which meant fewer were required to make the same amount of power.

Renewable energy cost high

Future Smart Strategies managing director Ray Wills said Fortescue was a "global, best practice leader" in operational decarbonisation.

However, he said the Nullagine project was "ambitious".

Ray Wills is a researcher, academic, consultant and futurist with a focus on sustainability and technology. (ABC News: Nicholas Martyr)

"The Pilbara is a difficult location to work for two reasons — one is the heat and cyclones," Professor Wills said.

"And the second reason is that your workforce has to be more expensive because you're FIFO."

The futurist said he did not think there would be an influx of new wind farms in Northern WA because it was still too expensive compared to the main alternative — solar.

The capacity of large-scale wind and solar power stations approved by the Clean Energy Regulator in Australia over the last five years. (Source: Clean Energy Regulator)

"Most certainly, wind has not reduced its price as quickly as solar has," he said.

"It can't be expensive energy, otherwise it will be expensive iron ore and on from there on to green iron.

"So we need to get the energy price continuously downwards."

title: Malnutrition and the KGB: Running away with the circus in 1990
text:
For most people, running away to join the circus is a fantasy or a joke.

But after graduating from Rosny College in Hobart in 1990, Dave Wellington's joke turned into reality.

What was meant to be a few days working for a show in Hobart turned into four months touring around Australia.

At 18, he and his mates, Gus and Joe, had no idea joining the circus would lead to malnutrition and being watched by the KGB.

Dave Wellington pulls a rope in 1990 as a worker with the Great Moscow Circus. (Supplied: Dave Wellington)

Working 17 hours a day, every day

Mr Wellington and his friends responded to an advertisement for labouring work with The Great Moscow Circus performing at the Derwent Entertainment Centre.

The job involved setting up and packing down the bell tents, stages and circus equipment.

There were bears, horses, dogs, and lots of Russian performers walking around them.

After a few days, they were asked whether they would like to join and travel with the circus as it toured Victoria, New South Wales, and Southeast Asia.

His mum and dad were less than impressed with his choice to join, as they were hoping he would apply to work at insurance companies or banks.

"You can imagine the look on both their faces when I said I'm hopping on a plane … and running away with the Moscow circus," he told ABC Afternoons.

"We worked for 17 hours a day on average for 7 days a week … [and] we were paid 2.81 per hour.

"It was hard work, but it was so enjoyable, and we met so many characters."

Trained bears performed for crowds. (Supplied: Dave Wellington)

Malnutrition and exhaustion

After a long day's work, Mr Wellington would head back to a caravan he shared with four others.

As a footy player at the time, he was physically active but said his fitness "suffered" over the next few months with the circus.

"We were living on hamburgers and Cornetto ice creams," he said.

"We just didn't have the ability to go and get fresh food nor did we have any cooking facilities.

"Despite working hard we didn't look after ourselves too well back then.

"The rule was in the caravan, we weren't allowed to have any food in the fridge, it was always beers.

" After around three and a half months, Gus was in hospital with malnutrition, and we were exhausted. "

Dave Wellington told his story on Tasmania Afternoons with ABC Radio Hobart. (Supplied: Dave Wellington)

The organisers would hire 100 to 200 labourers at each country town to help put the show on, according to Mr Wellington.

"There were a lot of people who were on the run," he said.

"A lot of blokes would turn up and not even give names, as I can imagine they were on bail and things like that.

"It was a bit of an eye opener at 18 years of age."

The Great Moscow Circus has been Australian-owned since the Soviet Union collapsed. (Supplied: Great Moscow Circus Facebook)

Watchful eye of the KGB

In 1990, the Great Moscow Circus was owned and run by the Soviet Union.

The KGB, or the Komitet Gosudarstvennoi Bezopanosti, were a feared security service for the Soviet Union.

"The KGB were the security … they were immaculately dressed every day, black shoes, black suit, black tie with a white shirt and scary looking big men," Mr Wellington said.

" The performers were not allowed to roam free, they were not allowed out of the area that was fenced off. "

He recalled a night they all snuck out with "Sasha the bear trainer", who had too much to drink and they all had to carry him back to the caravans without waking the KGB.

Looking back, he said it was very risky as Sasha would have been sent back to the Soviet Union if caught.

Mr Wellington would call his parents from a phone box and remembered his mum threatening to get on a plane to come get him.

"I said mum there's KGB, and she said, 'Well, they're not going to stop me,'" he said.

The Great Moscow Circus tours around Australia. (ABC Wide Bay: Scott Lamond)

Beautiful bonds along the road

It was a sad goodbye when the time came for the three Tasmanian boys to go home.

Many great relationships were made on the road, but one that stood out to Mr Wellington was a with another performer named Sasha, who was deaf.

"We were leaving on a bus at 6am and he had the KGB with him at the bus station and we gave him a hug," he said.

"As we drove off, and he was waving, it was just one of those moments where you look back and you think it's amazing to have a bond like that with someone that not only spoke a different language to you, but was also deaf."

The trademark name of the Great Moscow Circus was purchased by an Australian family after the collapse of the Soviet Union in December 1991.

The circus is still touring Australia today, but has changed since the early 90s, with new performances and regular security guards.

title: Irvine returns for St Pauli in major boost for Socceroos
text:
Socceroos midfielder Jackson Irvine has made a quick return from injury to help struggling St Pauli in the Bundesliga.

In a massive boost for Australian head coach Tony Popovic, Irvine came on as a substitute in the 63rd minute to earn his team a crucial point in their goalless draw against Hamburg on Friday night (Sat AEDT).

Barely 10 days ago, the relegation-threatened German outfit announced Irvine had suffered a foot injury and would be out indefinitely.

He subsequently missed the losses to Borussia Dortmund (3-2) and Wolfsburg (2-1), which plunged Kiezkicker (Neighbourhood Kickers) to joint-last position in the league.

Irvine has struggled for fitness and form in recent months. (Getty Images via Bundesliga: Boris Streubel )

Earlier this week, though, St Pauli's head coach Alexander Blessin said his skipper was a chance of playing.

"We are still in the testing phase. So we just have to see how his foot reacts," he told a news conference.

The point against derby rivals Hamburg lifted St Pauli to 16th spot — the relegation play-off position — but Blessin knows they face an uphill struggle.

"We did too little. We were very inactive, we were too slow. That's why we have to be happy with the point today," Blessin said after their lacklustre performance.

On the fight against relegation, he added: "It will be difficult. We need to start collecting points."

In August, Hamburg and St Pauli staged the first Hamburg derby in the Bundesliga in 14 years after both teams had stints in the second division. St Pauli won 2-0.

Irvine, who had to undergo foot surgery shortly before the end of last season and was out for a long time, has become a valued and respected member of the team since joining in 2021.

But he had made only eight appearances before Friday's clash given his injury hassles.

"He's the captain, he's the extended arm of the coaching team, and he's just extremely important," Blessin said.

His speedy return is bound to please the St Pauli faithful and also bring a sigh of relief to Popovic, just five months out from the World Cup to be jointly staged by the United States, Canada and Mexico.

Australia will play a European qualifier on June 14 (2pm) in Vancouver before meeting the United States on June 20 (5am) in Seattle. The Socceroos then take on Paraguay on June 26 (12pm) in Santa Clara in their final Group D match.

Before that Popovic's men will play friendlies against Cameroon at the Sydney Football Stadium in Sydney (March 27) and Curacao at AAMI Park in Melbourne (March 31).

Irvine is a vital cog in the Socceroos midfield and with 80 caps and 14 goals will add plenty of experience to the national team.

title: John Williamson takes his final bow at Tamworth Country Music Festival
text:
John Williamson's first memories of Tamworth weren't the famous country music festival, but rather the pain he felt during a rugby match.

"My earliest memory is playing rugby against one of the Tamworth teams … I actually broke my shoulder and I've still got a wire in it," he said.

Since then, his memories of the country music capital have changed to be filled with golden guitars, cowboy boots and plenty of music.

John Williamson says 2026 will be his last year performing at Tamworth. (ABC New England: Peter Sanders )

"I remember the old legends were still going, Slim Dusty and Buddy Williams performing, that's where it all started," he said.

After nearly 54 years at the festival, the Australian country music legend will headline the Tamworth stage for a final time.

"I was very much involved from the beginning. I was one of the five that started the Country Music Association of Australia and I've been part of getting it back to belonging to the musicians themselves," he said.

The Tamworth Country Music Festival hosts more than 300,000 attendees every year. (ABC News: Kemii Maguire)

"I think about all the different things that have happened over the years in Tamworth, all the different friends I've made.

" I just want everyone to know that I appreciate what Tamworth has done for Aussie songs. "

Although he's stepping away from the festival stage, Williamson said he would continue to write and record music, but he was ready for some time with family.

John Williamson describes returning to Tamworth each year as "nostalgic". (Supplied: Matt Williams)

"It's my 56th year in the business and I'm just a bit tired of being away from home," he said.

"I might do the odd local gig … it's just the travelling away and flying on aeroplanes, I'm sick of aeroplanes and sick of airports."

Williamson said he was not sure how he would feel after his final festival show, but he wanted to finish on a high note.

"I think it's good to pull out while I'm still doing good shows and I'm not having to read the lyrics or have monitors on the stage," he said.

"We'll see how I feel afterwards, but I mean, just about everybody that retires wants to come back and do it again."

John WIlliamson will say thank you to Tamworth at his final gig. (ABC Western Qld: Grace Nakamura)

Williamson is ready to hand the reins of Australian country music to the next generation; all he asks is they take care of them.

"It's time to let the young ones in and do what they want to do," he said.

"Make sure you keep it Australian, be yourself, and sing about what you know in this country.

"Aussie stories, we want to keep that going. Let's hope we don't let that fade in the future."

title: Perth's $290m film studios are finished, but there's nothing to shoot yet
text:
The Perth Film Studios appear almost as a mirage on the city's north-eastern fringe, backing onto largely undeveloped bushland as far as the eye can see.

The 16-hectare site on the fringes of Whiteman Park sits quiet for now, as the spacious buildings are put through their paces to make sure everything is right for the all-important first production.

The construction of Perth Film Studios was completed this week. (ABC News: Keane Bourke)

More than $233 million has already been spent creating four sound stages, two annexes and the southern hemisphere's biggest backlot in the hopes of attracting big name productions to the most isolated capital city in the world.

There's also hair, makeup and costume facilities, workshops to build sets and production offices.

Loading...

Another $57 million will be spend funding the management and operation of the facility, on top of $32 million of government subsidies dangled in front of prospective projects to lure them west.

"Around the world there's demand for screen content, whether that's for TV, streaming services, but also the big screen as well, and that's not going anywhere," Creative Industries Minister Simone McGurk said on Tuesday, announcing practical completion of the project.

One of Perth Film Studios' four sound stages. (ABC News: Keane Bourke)

"So we want to make sure that Western Australia is in a position to lean into that production demand."

The studio is yet to sign its first client — but it's coming soon, the studio's chief Tom Avison promises.

Perth Film Studios CEO Tom Avison says he has "tremendous confidence" the studios will be a success. (ABC News: Keane Bourke)

"Where we are with the conversations right now is exactly where I would expect to be and it gives me tremendous confidence," he said.

Diversification plan

The idea of building a film studio to help diversify WA's mining-reliant economy was floated before the 2021 election.

Then-Premier Mark McGowan had hoped to built it for around $100 million at Fremantle's Victoria Quay.

An artist's impression of what the film studios in Fremantle at Victoria Quay could have looked like. (Supplied)

But just over a year later those plans were put on ice after a closer look raised a range of potential problems at the same time construction costs were rising.

Ms McGurk was very keen this week to point out the second attempt came in on time and on budget.

The ultimate hope is for the studios to help grow Western Australia's screen industry by providing local work and training opportunities.

Simone McGurk speaking at the facility's unveiling. (ABC News: Keane Bourke)

Mr Avison acknowledged there would always be a need — particularly with the facility's early projects — to bring in experience from interstate and overseas.

But it's hoped that will change over time.

"We also want to bring back people, West Australians who felt they've had to move abroad or move elsewhere to work in this industry, they don't have to now, they can come back," he said.

Attracting international attention is also in the blueprint.

"Our dollar is incredibly great for projects not from Australia at the moment, from international, looking to make things on a budget," Screenwest CEO Rikki Lea-Bestall said.

"And the rest of Australia is full most of the time, there is limited infrastructure in Australia and there's limited infrastructure around the world.

Roger Cook described the studio as "world class". (ABC News: Keane Bourke)

"We were only talking to someone this week that is looking at something for eight months down the track and they cannot get into a film studio anywhere else in the entire world.

'A lot riding on it'

Richard Sowada is director of the Revelation Perth International Film Festival and is also optimistic about the studio's potential.

"When I started working in the WA screen sector more than 30 years ago, there was one feature film produced in WA every three years," he said.

Creative Industries Minister Simone McGurk, Perth Film Studios CEO Tom Avison and Premier Roger Cook hope to draw top-tier talent to the new facility. (ABC News: Keane Bourke)

"Now, it's really, really hard for the production crews to keep up with the work there's so much going on, which is really fantastic."

His one concern is the possibility that incentivising major projects to use the facility will come at the expense of lower-budget productions.

"Because there's a lot riding on it, and it takes a lot to feed," Mr Sowada said.

Richard Sowada has high hopes for what the studio will mean for the local film industry. (Supplied)

"Because the grassroots in Western Australia, the independent sector, is really doing it on their own — it would be good to see something like this be much more integrated."

Ms Lea-Bestall was confident the studios would benefit the local independent scene.

Almost $300 million has been invested in the facility. (ABC News: Keane Bourke)

"It's going to be a great couple of years," she said.

"It feels like it might have been a long time coming, and we're there.

"And we all want to make sure we have those opportunities for our kids and future generations to be in diverse industries, so we're very excited about that."

title: Rural council decides 'flanno' fashion is fine as business attire
text:
Mark Dal Bon said the community he represents wouldn't recognise him if he dressed in anything other than his black and white plaid shirt.

"That's how they've always seen me … it makes me feel confident in bringing the issues of the community up there [at council meetings] as well."

But the Griffith City councillor's choice of work attire was put under scrutiny when there were moves to change the dress code for councillors attending meetings late last year.

Mark Dal Bon is a councillor in Griffith in southern NSW, who campaigned in his flannel. (ABC Riverina: Nicola Ceccato )

It was proposed the standard dress code would be 'business casual,' and blazers would be provided for councillors to wear at meetings.

One submission suggested a councillor attending in a "clean flannelette shirt and jeans" may not meet the standard.

Council ultimately voted in favour of allowing flannelette shirts at meetings, but the debate has sparked broader discussion in the community about the changing nature of work wardrobes.

Flannelette shirts will now be considered appropriate business attire at Griffith City Council meetings. (ABC News: Jessica Clifford )

A changing landscape

Economic research released in August 2025 by employment site Indeed, shows job advertisements promoting relaxed dress standards have increased considerably in recent years.

The research shows employers in the ACT and Queensland are more likely to promote casual dress policies in job advertisements, with remote work driving demand for more comfortable workplace attire.

Mr Dal Bon said professionalism should be judged by cleanliness and presentation, rather than formality.

"You can't just go up in there [council meetings] in singlets, thongs, and shorts. In my flannelette shirt, I feel comfortable, and I personally think I look neat and tidy. I haven't gotten any complaints from the community."

Corporate stylist Kim Crowley says work attire standards have become a 'grey area'. (Supplied)

Corporate stylist Kim Crowley said people in politics are in a unique position to strike a balance between reliability and professionalism.

" For people out in rural areas, I think there is something really key about being able to reflect your people back at you. "

The trouble is with old-fashioned menswear suits is that it looks very assertive but can also look too assertive in and amongst people who are outdoors all day, working on farms."

Ms Crowley pointed to research around 'enclothed cognition,' which suggests clothing can influence performance.

"If we dress more professionally and like we're going to perform better, our cognitive behaviour actually increases. If you want to be able to be taken seriously and succeed in your workplace, you should dress the part," she said.

A 'grey area'

Ms Crowley said employers have broadly embraced business casual in recent years, but unclear expectations can cause confusion and even tension.

"There are always a few people in office environments where they're not getting it right," Ms Crowley said.

"There's a middle ground that could be more relaxed than a suit, but maybe not as relaxed as a flannelette shirt.

"And the nuances, that's what people miss," she said.

Ms Crowley said first impressions still mattered, particularly in front-facing roles, where people could be judged "in the blink of an eye".

Etiquette expert Amanda King said work attire standards have become too casual over the years. (Supplied. )

Amanda King from the Australian Finishing School said people's work attire standards have changed.

"I know Australia has a reputation for being quite a casual society, but there is still a level of respect for yourself and for everyone else to put on something clean and decent for the day and put in the effort."

She believes a more formal approach to workwear can help people have more impact and influence in their positions.

"If you're dressed well and you're dressed appropriately, people treat you better and they respect you. They trust what you're saying a little bit more," she said.

But for Mr Dal Bon, given he's been cleared to wear his beloved flannelettes in council meetings, he won't be changing up his gear anytime soon.

"As long as people feel comfortable in what they're wearing, I think that's what really brings out the professionalism in them," he said.

title: Live: Early start to beat heatwave in Melbourne, as Sinner, Djokovic, Osaka set for centre court
text:
As Melbourne and much of Australia braces for heatwave conditions, day seven of the Australian Open has an early start to maximise play before temperatures peak, as Jannik Sinner, Novak Djokovic and Naomi Osaka feature in matches on centre court.

Temperatures are expected to reach the low 30s by the middle of the day, peaking at 40 degrees later in the afternoon.

Tonight, Djokovic will continue his quest for an 11th Australian Open title against Botic van de Zandschulp on Rod Laver Arena, followed by Naomi Osaka taking on Australian qualifier Maddison Inglis.

Others in action on day seven include women's second seed Iga Świątek, fifth seed Elena Rybakina and Swiss veteran Stan Wawrinka — the latter up against American Taylor Fritz in what could be his last Australian Open match.

Follow all the latest from Melbourne Park in our live blog below.

title: The history behind the largest Kalymnian Greek expat community in the world
text:
Born and raised in Darwin, I've always longed for a place I've never known.

Stories of my family's migration from Greece followed me throughout my childhood. How Darwin came to be for us has been a defining narrative.

Our Australian chapter began with my late father at Fremantle Port walking off the Cyrenia, after a 28-day journey from Greece in 1956.

Alone at 18, wearing his only pair of shoes and carrying a suitcase, he made his way to Darwin to work as a carpenter.

Iraklis Roussos worked as a carpenter in Australia, after his migration from Greece in 1956. (ABC News: Pete Garnish)

Four years later at age 12, my mother left Greece with her family bound for Darwin.

There in the classroom of Parap Primary School she sat, confused by a language she didn't understand.

Eleni Roussos's mother Irene Roussos (nee Hatzigeorgiou) remembers feeling displaced when she started school in Darwin. (Supplied)

While working at a cafe run by her auntie, my mother met my father and a few years later they married, going on to have seven children, with me their youngest.

Both my parents are from Kalymnos in the Dodecanese (near Türkiye) that is home to 16,000 people.

It's an island of only 100 square kilometres known for its sponge diving and limestone rock climbing.

About 16,000 people live on the Greek island of Kalymnos. (ABC News: Eleni Roussos)

It shares a sister-city relationship with Darwin, where 10 per cent of the city's population is of Greek heritage, with the majority hailing from the same island as my parents.

In a city that's home to so many Greeks, getting to know my culture has come easy.

Growing up, weekends were spent attending cultural name days under troppo homes, mammoth weddings in suburban halls or at the one Orthodox church that has united Darwin's Kalymnians for generations.

Irene Roussos, Eleni's mother has lived in Darwin for the past 65 years. (ABC News: Pete Garnish)

A bronze statue of a water bearer that stands on a plinth in Darwin's main mall — that marks the city's strong ties to Kalymnos — has been a signpost to my history all my life.

The statue, made in Greece, was inspired by my great grandmother, whose name I share, Eleni Roussou (nee Troumouliaris).

She was a refugee, whose husband was killed in a skirmish during the Ottomon Empire's decline in what is now Türkiye.

Expelled, she fled to Kalymnos with her five children, where she worked as a housemaid for a wealthy family.

A bronze Kalimnia statue, which was inspired by journalist Eleni Roussos's great grandmother, stands at Darwin's main mall. (ABC News: Pete Garnish)

To supplement her income as a single mother, she delivered fresh spring water in clay pots to homes for a fee, becoming the first woman to sell water on the island.

Her story of survival inspired local artist George Economou to create a painting of a water bearer in her honour.

Kalymnian sculptor Michael Kokkinos and his daughter Erini were later commissioned to turn the image into sculptures, known as the "Kalimnia", which to this day can be found all across the island.

A refugee during the Ottomon Empire's decline, Eleni Roussos's story of survival was memorialised by statues across Kalymnos island. (ABC News: Eleni Roussos)

Darwin-Kalymnos connection

I arrived in Kalymnos for the summer of 2025, after navigating a health scare that brought my mortality to the fore.

I ran into familiar faces from back home at every cafe, tavern and beach and stopped the car to take a pic of "Darwin Street".

On the Greek island of Kalymnos, there is a place called 'Darwin street'. (ABC News: Eleni Roussos)

Talking to locals, it became clear the role migration has had on Kalymnos's identity and how central my hometown has been to the island's economic prosperity.

Katie and George Tavlarios ran a successful hotel in Kalymnos before Greece's 2009 economic collapse crippled the business.

A return to Darwin, where Katie was born, became the only viable option.

"In the beginning it was hard because I had to leave my children behind for three years and that was the most difficult part," Katie said.

George and Katie Tavlarios, on holiday in Kalymnos, are the owners of Meraki Greek tavern in Darwin. (ABC News: Eleni Roussos)

The couple spent a decade working in labouring and hospitality jobs before opening their own Greek tavern in Darwin with their children.

They say the city has given them a lifeline.

"Life was really hard, it was stressful, thank God I had the possibility to go to Australia, if not, I don't know what we were going to do in Greece," George said.

'A lot to thank Darwin for': Post-war migration boom

The post-World War II period saw a massive wave of impoverished Kalymnians leave the island for foreign shores.

The story of their departure and subsequent contribution was nowhere to be seen in the public displays of Kalymnian history.

Over the last several decades many Kalymnians have left their home in search for better economic opportunities. (ABC News: Eleni Roussos)

This absence prompted me to meet with Deputy Mayor Popi Koutouzi, who, like most on the island had a Darwin family connection.

"This island has a lot to thank Darwin for," Ms Koutouzi said.

"If you take into consideration that 90 per cent of the people that left Kalymnos to immigrate in Australia went to Darwin, you can imagine how big the role of Darwin is in everyday life in Kalymnos.

Popi Koutouzi is the Deputy Mayor of Kalymnos island in Greece. (ABC News: Eleni Roussos)

"The male members of the family went to Darwin to work, and they would send money to Kalymnos to support their mothers, wives and sisters.

" Without that financial support coming from Darwin, the families could not live here. "

Other Greek islands heavily rely on tourism. Kalymnos is different thanks to its large diaspora.

"July and August is packed with second and third generation Kalymnians who are coming back to the island on holiday … this is financial support for the island," she said.

Many Kalymnians return to their Greek hometown for a summer holiday. (ABC News: Eleni Roussos)

Ms Koutouzi says migration is a "big part of Kalymnian life" that warrants more attention on the island.

"I see exhibitions and photographs of the sponge divers and photographs of other topics, but never one that celebrates the people who left to go somewhere else … the ones who never got to come back at all".

From Aegean waters to the Arafura Sea

The first group of Kalymnians — some 12 men — were brought to Darwin and Broome in the 1950s to collect pearl shell.

But the murky tropical waters and huge tidal waves made the Australian government's diving experiment with Kalymnians short lived.

Kalymnian shipwrights working on a pearl lugger in Darwin in the 1950s. (Supplied: Paspaley)

Seeing the opportunity for land-based work, thousands of Kalymnians came to Darwin, making the city home to the largest Kalymnian expat community in the world.

Former NT administrator John Anictomatis left Piraeus in Athens with his mother and brothers in 1955 when he was nine to join his father in Darwin.

He has borne witness to the impact of Greek migration on Darwin throughout his 35 years as the Honorary Greek Consul for the NT.

John Anictomatis says Greek migrants played an integral role in Darwin’s growth as a modern city. (ABC News: Michael Franchi)

"I think Darwin would be a different place if it wasn't for the Greek involvement in the industries that they were involved in — fishing, pearling, mining, construction — you name it," Mr Anictomatis said.

He remembers how the handful of Greek students at his primary school — which was also my mother's — made sense of their new home.

"I was told many times: 'Don't speak to any newcomers in Greek, speak to them in English'. We couldn't help it, we'd converse in Greek," he said.

Eleni Roussos has been reflecting on her family's migration history, and looking at old photos with her mother. (ABC News: Pete Garnish)

Since the trip to Greece, I have been contemplating place and cultural identity.

While there is no official monument recognising the people who left Kalymnos — to me — my great grandmother's statue embodies all the immigrants who toil in foreign lands.

To me, she represents the migrant experience of holding onto the dream that their children may one day know the place their ancestors once called home.

title: How the Australian Open keeps its cool during a heatwave
text:
With temperatures set to soar across the long weekend, there's a chance play at the Australian Open could be suspended.

Matches will start an hour earlier than usual on day seven in an attempt to avoid as much of the heat as possible.

The tournament has already seen some impacts of heat after a ball girl collapsed on court when Zeynep Sönmez took on 11th seed Ekaterina Alexandrova.

Zeynep Sonmez helped a ball kid after they collapsed due to heat during her first round match. (Reuters: Edgar Su)

Victoria, along with much of the country's south east, will experience a prolonged severe heatwave from Saturday, which has the potential to break all-time temperature records.

Melbourne is tipped to hit 40 degrees Celsius on Saturday, with a total fire ban declared for the entire state.

A cool change will then move through, but it won't last long. The heat will ramp up again on Tuesday, with the temperature forecast to reach 44C in the outer suburbs of Melbourne.

It will be unavoidable for athletes and revellers at the tennis, but there are some things they can do to keep cool in the heat.

How does the heat affect players?

Thermal physiologist Matt Brearley said while well-trained athletes were able to better tolerate heatwaves, they still had limits.

"Our bodies are like internal combustion engines — the harder we work, the harder we play, the more heat we produce," Dr Brearley said.

"For some people, getting up into the high 38s, low 39s, they'll start to see symptoms such as headache, fatigue, irritability and nausea.

"If it gets much higher, they'll probably see some central nervous system impairments such as confusion, delirium … [It's] extremely dangerous at that point, because the body and the brain is impacted."

He said athletes were "extremely heat acclimatised" as a result of their training, but could still experience heat stroke, which could be deadly.

It's why heat policies exist.

Novak Djokovic needed some cooling off during his first round match against Pedro Martinez. (AAP Image: James Ross)

What is Tennis Australia doing about the heat?

Extreme heat at the Australian Open is not uncommon. Every year, there are at least a few days where temperatures are above 30C during the tournament.

In 2014, a four-day heatwave — which melted bottles courtside — saw a record number of players pull out of the tournament and led to many complaints from athletes and spectators.

The Australian Open introduced a new heat policy in 2018 determined by a measure called the Heat Stress Scale.

It takes into account four climate factors which determine heat stress — the temperature, radiant heat, humidity and wind speed.

These factors are recorded by a device called an environmental management unit, or EMU by the side of courts at Melbourne park, and are put into an algorithm which creates a five-point scale.

The Australian Open's heat stress scale ranges from one to five. (Supplied: University of Sydney)

The scale, which looks similar to the fire danger rating scale, then triggers certain rules in relation to heat for players.

If the scale reaches five, matches will be called off.

All-time attendance records were shattered at the Australian Open this year. (AAP Image: Lukas Coch)

Tennis Australia chief executive Craig Tiley said there may be a break in the tennis on Saturday in the late afternoon due to the heat.

"Our Bureau of Meteorology experts are telling us probably sometime [on Saturday] afternoon … between 3 and 6pm, we could be at that point," he said.

How can spectators stay cool?

Water misters are littered throughout the grounds and there are plenty of shady places, particularly near hydration stations.

Dr Brearley said while hydration was essential on hot days, by itself it may not be enough for a lot of people.

"Most people want to cool down when they get hot," he said.

"But what you can do is actually cool our body before you get hot and give yourself a greater window for heat storage and [for athletes] improved performance early in the match."

How to do that, he said, was by pre-cooling.

Athletes will often jump into an ice bath or ingest crushed ice drinks before they expose themselves to heat and spectators at the tennis can achieve the same effect by eating icy-poles or slushies.

"Melting ice in your body, changing it from a solid to a liquid, requires a phenomenal amount of heat," he said.

"That's our body heat that melts the ice and so basically, by transferring body heat to the ice, you're creating a heat sink internally."

title: Queensland's oldest tennis club grows from 12 members to 600 in six years
text:
Membership at Queensland's oldest continuous tennis club has jumped nearly 5,000 per cent in the past six years.

But to be fair, the growth came off a pretty low base, says Toowoomba's Range Tennis club president Paul Mooney.

"In 2020 there were a dozen or so members," Mr Mooney said.

"This year we're just shy of 600, which has been phenomenal."

Paul Mooney is the coach and club president of the Range Tennis Club. (ABC Southern Qld: Grace Nakamura)

Mr Mooney said the club, founded in 1893, had bucked a trend in declining participation rates.

Its rapid growth defies the well-worn narrative of regional sports clubs that struggle from dwindling populations and lack of volunteers.

New players sign in and pay for two hours of social tennis. (ABC Southern Qld: Grace Nakamura)

Mr Mooney said the key to changing the trajectory of the four-court club was to build a strong junior membership base by coordinating tournaments for kids.

"Kids now start off with coaching, they will hire courts, and then morph into playing tournaments and fixtures," Mr Mooney said.

There are now 300 juniors signed up to the club, compared to none in 2019.

There are now 300 junior members at the Range Tennis Club. (ABC Southern Qld: Grace Nakamura)

Next generation takes the court

Patrick Freeman, 13, can be found smacking back forehands to the often-adult players at the other end of the court four times a week.

"There are a lot of kids around my age that play here," Patrick said.

Patrick Freeman is one of 300 juniors now playing at the Range Tennis Club. (ABC Southern Qld: Grace Nakamura)

"Over my Christmas holidays, I've seen so many new faces here who I've never seen before."

His mother, Annabel Freeman, joined the club as treasurer after seeing how much Patrick enjoyed playing.

"I thought I'd do what I could to keep the club going," Ms Freeman said.

" I don't think you could oversell the importance of [community clubs], especially these ground-level clubs that are happy to take on kids at any level and grow them up. "

Patrick and Annabel Freeman are at the club multiple times a week for tennis training and fixtures. (ABC Southern Qld: Grace Nakamura)

Growth in membership

Range Tennis Club secretary Tony Brown, 84, said Toowoomba's tennis landscape had been in dire straits a decade ago.

Another Toowoomba tennis club Mr Brown played at folded due to a lack of members, so he transferred to the Range club in 2013.

Tony Brown has been the club secretary for about a decade. (ABC Southern Qld: Grace Nakamura)

"I came here and there were a whole 12 members — whoopee," he said.

"Where do you go with us oldies if you don't have a follow-up brigade with the parents of the children, and the children themselves to take [tennis] to the next generation?"

Surprisingly, he said it was the COVID-19 pandemic that helped to revive the club because it turned out tennis was the perfect sport to play while socially distanced.

Players fill up the synthetic grass courts at the Range Tennis Club. (ABC Southern Qld: Grace Nakamura)

Keeping overheads low

Mr Mooney, a former nationally ranked player, saw an opportunity for growth when he joined as the club president and coach in 2020.

"Toowoomba is Australia's second-largest inland city, and our tennis participation numbers were pretty low for a city that size," he said.

" We had the perfect storm just based on the size of the city and the lack of people playing tennis. "

More young families with children have joined the tennis club since the pandemic. (ABC Southern Qld: Grace Nakamura)

Toowoomba has a population of 173,304, according to the 2021 census.

Mr Mooney's expertise as a coach and his lifelong dedication to the sport attracted $60,000 in sponsorships from local businesses, which helped keep the cost of court hire and annual memberships low, to just $10 an hour and $35 a year respectively.

He said an arrangement with the Queensland government to lease the land for $1 per year was also a saviour.

Thursday night is social night for club members. (ABC Southern Qld: Grace Nakamura)

'Think outside the box'

Community groups and sports clubs in regional and rural towns across the country struggle to retain members.

La Trobe University senior sports lecturer Pam Kappelides said what the Range club had accomplished was rare because fewer people were volunteering at clubs after the pandemic.

The social tennis season has begun for 2026. (ABC Southern Qld: Grace Nakamura)

"It goes back to that ageing population and population decline in smaller towns, so the number of people available to support the clubs are not there," she said.

"The financial pressures for rural communities, often farming communities, means they're unable to prioritise sport."

She said the survival of regional sport clubs hinged on their ability to "think outside the box".

"Don't just think 'That's how it's always run,'" she said.

"Think about perhaps how the population is changing in their needs and what they want from the club."

title: Should financial literacy be mandatory in schools?
text:
In an increasingly complex financial world of buy-now-pay-later schemes, scams, and social media marketing designed to encourage spending over saving, there are renewed calls for financial literacy to become a mandatory part of the school curriculum.

It comes amid concerns students are leaving school without basic financial knowledge about tax, superannuation, and budgeting.

"Along with women, young people between the ages of 12 and 24 are the most financially illiterate demographic," Financial Basics Foundation chief executive Katrina Samios said.

Tasmanian Labor Senator Richard Dowling has been pushing for the need to strengthen financial literacy for young people and across the wider community.

"Forty years ago, sex education moved from taboo to essential," he said.

"Financial literacy deserves the same whole-of-society focus."

Katrina Samios says young people between the ages of 12 and 24 are the most financially illiterate demographic. (ABC News: Richard Sydenham)

With the cost of living continuing to rise, being able to manage money will be more important than ever for younger generations, according to Ms Samios.

"They're working and living as part of the gig economy, a cashless society," she said.

" So they're managing digital payments without actually understanding the basics even [those] such as simple bank account products. "

Educating students through 'side hustle'

Alyssia Kennedy, 29, felt she had missed out on some important life lessons around money when she left school.

"I know how lost I felt," Ms Kennedy said.

"I ended up with very unexpected bills.

"I found myself wondering, 'how am I going to pay for this bill?' because I didn't budget for it, and I didn't know how to budget either, so I was navigating a lot."

Now working full-time, Ms Kennedy has decided to share her knowledge about all things financial — as well as some general life lessons — with a younger generation.

Alyssia Kennedy visits schools around Tasmania, talking about tax, superannuation, renting and insurance. (ABC News: Mackenzie Heard)

Describing it as a "side hustle", Ms Kennedy visits schools around Tasmania, talking about concepts like tax, superannuation, renting and insurance.

Students are encouraged to weigh up the costs of buying groceries versus take-away food, they're given meal-planning tips, and basic budgeting lessons.

"With this knowledge, I really want to be able to empower young people to be able to make these decisions and have a conversation about it now, so when they do leave school, they are prepared," she said.

Alyssia Kennedy says she wants to empower young people to make savvy financial decisions. (ABC News: Mackenzie Heard)

Students 'surprised' by expenses

For year 10 students at Marist Regional College in Burnie in Tasmania's North West, taking part in Ms Kennedy's Life After School Program has been eye-opening.

"I was definitely surprised by all the expenses," Harry Hodgetts said.

"Even renting a house — like sharing with others — there's a lot of hidden expenses."

Marist Regional College students say the Life After School Program has been eye-opening. (ABC News: Mackenzie Heard)

Olivia Wyllie said: "We're all starting to get jobs and get cars and life's starting to get a bit more serious and I feel we don't know as much as we think we do."

How financial literacy changed this high school Four years ago almost half of the students left this Brisbane high school without plans for work or study — financial literacy has turned that around.

Jobe Pringle said he was interested to learn more about budgeting.

"I definitely spend more than I make, I chip into my parents' money a bit more," he said.

Marist deputy principal Emily Sass said the program helped fill a gap in an already packed curriculum.

"Some of us adults have learnt these things the hard way so we've had some conversations about 'wouldn't it be great to have known some of this beforehand'," she said.

"The more we can equip them, especially in the current climate, the better off they'll be."

Emily Sass says the program helps fill a gap in an already packed curriculum. (ABC News: Mackenzie Heard)

Half of Australian adults considered financially illiterate

Some financial concepts are taught in schools across a range of different subjects, but there are calls for it to be a mandatory stand-alone subject.

"When we have it as a non-compulsory elective stream … It means that it's not delivered consistently and it's optional.

" Which is why we're still seeing young people come out of secondary school without having learnt any of these important topics. "

How to involve your kids in back-to-school budgeting Managing back-to-school costs, especially when kids want expensive brand name items, can cause a lot of stress for families. But including children in the budgeting process is key to helping everyone get on the same page.

Ms Samios said young people were increasingly sourcing information about money from social media.

"It's difficult to navigate what is real and correct information and financial advice ... and also it's not personalised."

According to the 2020 Household, Income and Labour Dynamics in Australia Study (HILDA), only around half of Australian adults can demonstrate an understanding of at least three basic financial literacy concepts.

"That's a striking indicator of how widespread the gap is," Senator Dowling said.

He said he was lobbying relevant ministers about the need for financial literacy to be taught in schools.

Richard Dowling has been pushing for the need to strengthen financial literacy among young people. (ABC News: Luke Bowden)

"Progress in education reform never happens overnight and requires agreement across jurisdictions, but I am encouraged by the momentum we have — both within the parliament and right across the community," he said.

In New Zealand, financial education will be embedded in the curriculum for students from year 1 to 10, starting this year.

In the United States, the majority of states require students to complete a stand-alone personal finance course before graduating from high school.

Education Minister Jason Clare said financial literacy was part of the curriculum, but some students were left behind.

"The most important thing we can do for financial literacy is make sure that school students are getting the basics in maths and numeracy," he said.

"It's really important you get the basics early. If you don't get the basics right, you can't build on them.

"It's why we've brought forward work on the current maths curriculum for K-2 [kinder to year 2 students]."

"This is the first targeted review of the curriculum as part of the new curriculum review cycle."

title: Future of Canberra's Black Mountain Tower in limbo as Ngunnawal cultural site plans stall
text:
The future of Canberra's iconic Black Mountain Tower is under the spotlight again, with concerns a commitment to transform it into a Ngunnawal cultural tourism venue has been put on ice.





Richie Allan and Aunty Violet Sheridan says Ngunnawal people feel excluded. (ABC News: Monte Bovill) The 195-metre tower continues to act as a telecommunications facility, but the site has been closed to the public since 2021.

In 2023, Telstra announced plans to restore the site as a "premier destination" that celebrates Ngunnawal culture.

But Ngunnawal custodian Richie Allan said there had been little movement.

"Telstra did make a promise to the Ngunnawal people that it will be a Ngunnawal cultural centre," Mr Allan said.

" We are going to make Telstra accountable … they made a promise, and we are going to make sure they stick to that promise. "

Mr Allan said Ngunnawal people had felt excluded from key conversations about the future of the tower, particularly since the ACT government and Telstra signed an agreement in mid-2024 to work together on the site's reopening.

"Ngunnawal people get pushed aside, Ngunnawal culture gets put under the rug … we are sick of it," he said.

Independent MLAs join push to honour traditional owners

The calls for more certainty around the project have been backed by independent ACT senator David Pocock and independent MLA Thomas Emerson.

"This is a Canberra icon that we could and should be using to celebrate the traditional owners of this land," Mr Emerson said.





David Pocock says the Canberra icon should be used to celebrate the region's traditional owners. (ABC News: Monte Bovill) "Let's take advantage of that opportunity and not let this opportunity fall by the wayside."

Talks between ACT government, Telstra continue

In a statement, an ACT government spokesperson said they wanted to ensure the tower's reopening delivered "meaningful cultural opportunities" and that there had already been "positive discussions" with traditional custodians.

"Community feedback to date supports a staged, transparent process, with formal engagement to commence once commercial negotiations between Telstra and the government are finalised," the spokesperson said.

"While Telstra has previously consulted traditional custodians on potential future uses of the site, including a cultural centre, those outcomes remain a matter for Telstra as the facility owner."





Andrew Barr says he was unsatisfied with Telstra's offers last November. (ABC News: Matt Roberts) Earlier this week, the Chief Minister met with Aunty Violet Sheridan as a representative of Traditional Custodians, to discuss the future of the tower.

The spokesperson said over the next 12 months, the government would "work with Telstra to finalise commercial arrangements and refurbishment planning for the first stage of the tower re-opening project with the available budget".

In November last year, Chief Minister Andrew Barr said the territory was not satisfied with offers from Telstra, as part of negotiations for the redevelopment of the tower.

Staged tower reopening planned for 2027

The reopening of the tower is expected to be done in stages, with late 2027 the current target period for stage one.





A Telstra spokesperson says the company is committed to engaging with traditional custodians. (ABC News: Monte Bovill) "This remains subject to ongoing commercial negotiations, the successful procurement of a construction partner and the construction works proceeding smoothly," the ACT government spokesperson said.

A Telstra spokesperson said it was "critically important" that Ngunnawal traditional custodians were a part of the planning process.

"The ACT government is leading this engagement and is in the process of developing its engagement plan with the support of its specialist advisors," Telstra said.

"We've appreciated the positive conversations to date and are committed to continuing this engagement."

title: Queensland researchers are using a popular pet fish to test rare genetic variants
text:
Two tiny babies born on different sides of the world have avoided medical treatment costing millions of dollars, thanks to an Australian-based scientist and his tanks of zebrafish.

The babies — a boy in NSW and a girl in Germany — were born in 2023 with unusual variants of the gene that causes spinal muscular atrophy (SMA), detected in newborn screening.

Neither newborn had a family history of the condition, affecting an estimated one in 10,000 babies worldwide.

Both babies were born with variants that were previously unknown to science, making it impossible for their doctors to know whether they would develop the condition — or not.

Griffith University biomedical scientist Jean Giacomotto holds up a tank of Zebrafish in his lab at the Institute for Biomedicine and Glycomics. (Supplied: Griffith University)

That created a dilemma. Should medical specialists start treatment, risking unnecessary intervention, with potential side effects? Or, should they delay therapy, risking irreversible harm?

The Australian Functional Genomics Network, established to enhance the understanding of genetic variants, turned to Griffith University biomedical scientist Jean Giacomotto, and his zebrafish, for clarity.

Spinal muscular atrophy is caused by mutations in the SMN1 (survivor motor neuron 1) gene, leading to a lack of a protein, which is needed for motor neuron survival.

In the past, children with the most common form of the genetic condition, SMA type 1, have died before the age of two.

However, three treatments have emerged in the past decade, including a one-off gene therapy drug, Zolgensma, which costs about $2 million.

All must be initiated before symptoms appear to avoid irreversible motor neuron death and the long-term effects of the treatment are unknown.

Dr Giacomotto, of Griffith University's Institute for Biomedicine and Glycomics, used zebrafish to show both babies' SMN1 variants would not result in the disorder.

Dr Giacomotto injected the babies' SMN1 variants into zebrafish embryos that were bred without the gene. (Supplied: Griffith University)

He did so in less than six weeks, replicating the results.

Zebrafish are a home aquarium favourite with eye-catching stripes. But they are also proving to be a useful tool for researchers studying neurological conditions, such as spinal muscular atrophy.

Dr Giacomotto said zebrafish bred without a SMN1 gene, developed a form of the neuromuscular condition, resulting in degeneration of the spine, progressive loss of motor function and premature death.

They die within about six days, rather than the usual zebrafish life span of about two years.

But when he used a precision injection technique to introduce the babies' SMN1 variants into zebrafish embryos bred without the gene, he found they survived.

"We were able to functionally test each baby's exact mutation and show it was not harmful," Dr Giacomotto said.

A developing zebrafish viewed from the side, with muscle fibres in red and motor neurons in white, helping researchers track disease progression and study the impact of genetic variants. (Supplied: Griffith University)

"This research provides the clearest demonstration to date that zebrafish can play a decisive role in clinical variant interpretation, particularly in newborns flagged through expanding genomic screening programs.

"With genomic sequencing rising worldwide, clinicians are encountering more and more uncertain variants.

" This tiny fish offers a fast and affordable way to help resolve these cases and reduce distress for families. "

The children at the centre of the research are more than two years old and are developing normally.

Dr Giacomotto's research features on the front cover of the latest edition of the scientific journal EMBO Molecular Medicine.

University of NSW-based paediatric neurologist Michelle Farrar, who was also part of the research, described it as a "game-changer".

Zebrafish in the lab. (Supplied: Griffith University)

"It really is the first time this model's been used in a timely way that really supports clinical decision making to get the best management for the child and certainty for the families," Professor Farrar said.

She said gene therapy for babies with spinal muscular atrophy was only subsidised in Australia on the Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme for children with a definitive diagnosis.

"Our newborn screening guidelines say that if you have an uncertain result, that they need to be followed up until it's clarified and so, this research was really important," she said.

The luminous bodies of zebrafish larvae make it easy for researchers to observe specific particular features. (Supplied: Griffith University)

The researchers suggest zebrafish could become a "valuable model" for testing genetic variants of uncertain significance, not only for spinal muscular atrophy, but for human disease generally.

"We are seeing an explosion of new gene variants associated with a diversity of disorders," they wrote in the scientific journal. "The determination of their functional consequences is posing a significant challenge, and this problem will continue to grow with the development and need for precision/personalised medicine. "The zebrafish can help address this translational need."

Loading...

Australian Regenerative Medicine Institute director of research Peter Currie, who was not involved in the study, described the breakthrough as a "huge success story for modern medicine".

Professor Currie, who uses zebrafish to research muscular dystrophy, said zebrafish were a "well-established" model for the study of human disease, with the freshwater fish sharing 70 per cent of its genes with humans.

Zebrafish embryos are also translucent, allowing scientists to study internal biological processes, including neuromuscular development.

Australian Regenerative Medicine Institute director of research, Professor Peter Currie, who uses zebrafish to study muscular dystrophy. (Supplied)

The Monash University-based researcher described Professor Giacomotto's zebrafish work as a "really clever way to use the model to speed up the diagnostic process".

Professor Currie said zebrafish were also a useful model to screen experimental drugs for the treatment of human disease, including cancer.

title: Hundreds injured in Melbourne’s e-scooter trial, new data shows
text:
Advertisement

Exclusive NationalVictoriaPublic transport Hundreds injured in Melbourne’s e-scooter trial, new data shows Patrick Hatch January 24, 2026 — 1:00pm Save You have reached your maximum number of saved items. Remove items from your saved list to add more. Save this article for later Add articles to your saved list and come back to them anytime. Got it Share A A A

More than 500 people reported being injured – including 17 seriously – in crashes while riding or being hit by a hired e-scooter during Melbourne’s controversial two-and-a-half-year experiment with hire scheme operators Lime and Neuron. Data obtained by The Age reveals for the first time the number of injured riders and pedestrians recorded after the e-scooter trial was launched across inner Melbourne in early 2022. A Neuron scooter in South Melbourne on Friday. The scheme is still operating in the Port Phillip council area. Luis Enrique Ascui The City of Melbourne abruptly cancelled its contract with Lime and Neuron in August 2024, with Lord Mayor Nick Reece saying scooters were “creating havoc” on CBD footpaths. Lime and Neuron withdrew from the City of Yarra in March last year after the council increased its daily fee to from $1 to $5 per scooter to cover the cost of managing the scheme, but they continue to operate in the City of Port Phillip.

Advertisement

The state government declared the hire-scooter trial a success and legalised both hire schemes and privately owned e-scooters in July 2024. But it refused at the time to release information on the number of crashes and injuries recorded. Data obtained by The Age via a freedom-of-information request shows Lime and Neuron received 558 reports of injuries involving its scooters across the three local council areas between February 2022 and August 2024. Of those injuries, 180 people required medical treatment. Sixteen were admitted to hospital for more than 24 hours, and one scooter rider suffered life-threatening injuries. There were no fatal crashes. Pedestrians and other third-parties hit by hire scooter riders accounted for 37 injuries, including 15 who needed medical treatment and four who were admitted to hospital treatment for more than 24 hours.

Advertisement

The data shows Lime and Neuron also received 4837 complaints about poorly parked scooters and recorded 407 “water vehicles” – meaning scooters that were dumped in rivers, lakes or the ocean. Lime and Neuron said the injury data showed their scooters were a relatively safe form of transport, considering customers took 9.4 million trips over that period, with 99.994 per cent of journeys ending safely and 0.073 serious injuries reported per 100,000 kilometres travelled. However, Reece said ending the e-scooter contract was “absolutely the right decision”. “Too many people were being injured, and we acted to put safety first,” he said. “Unsafe riding and abandoned scooters blocking footpaths created real risks for pedestrians.” The data does not capture privately owned e-scooters, which have been involved in fatal crashes in Victoria and have become the focus of public concern along with high-powered e-bikes.

Advertisement

Will Peters, head of Asia Pacific for Lime, said that unlike privately owned e-scooters, its devices were speed-limited to 20km/h, insured and operated with public oversight. Related Article E-Scooters The e-scooter loophole that left crash victim struggling to get by “We are proud of the e-scooter service we provided in Melbourne, helping tens of thousands of residents and visitors travel more sustainably throughout the city,” he said. A spokesperson for Neuron said Melbourne was one of its busiest cities worldwide for e-scooter trips before the City of Melbourne suspended its partnership. “The vast majority of riders were behaving responsibly,” they said. But for those injured, the harm has been significant and long-lasting.

Advertisement

Adelaide woman Julia Miller suffered a broken shoulder and elbow when she was hit by a Lime scooter rider near the MCG in April 2022. Almost four years later, the 63-year-old still has limited use of one arm and sometimes uses a walker because of difficult balancing and related neck pain. “It’s been a major impact on my life in terms of everyday function,” she said. Julia Miller, who was hit by a hire scheme scooter near the MCG, pictured in 2022. Ben Searcy Miller said she was glad to see the City of Melbourne eventually ended the scooter schemes, but said councils should have put more resources into ensuring they were used safely. “These are big, heavy machines. If you jump on a bicycle you know how to ride it, but anyone can ride a scooter without knowing how to use it,” she said. Miller is pursuing compensation from Lime for her injuries.

Advertisement

Pedestrians hit by hire scooters early in the trial found they were unable to claim on Lime and Neuron’s insurance policies if the rider was not wearing a helmet or breaking other road rules. Nick Mann, principal at compensation firm Polaris Lawyers, said his firm had received numerous inquiries from people seriously injured by e-scooters. Mann said the insurance policies had improved but still had “critical gaps which are likely to leave people without coverage if they are injured by a rental scooter”. “We continue to recommend that Lime and other private rental companies should be required to pay to register e-scooters with the TAC scheme to provide better protection for injured Victorians,” he said. Port Phillip Mayor Alex Makin said he was comfortable continuing to work with Lime and Neuron, with hire scooters providing a valuable service to cover gaps in the public transport network. Makin said there were 31,000 hire scooter trips and five reported minor incidents in December. “E-scooter usage appears to be unequivocally responsible,” he said.

Advertisement

Makin said safety and amenity concerns had been addressed by Lime and Neuron implementing footpath-riding detection technology, slow-riding and no-go zones and no-parking zones. “There’s a greater level of comfort with how e-scooters are used in our community,” Makin said. “Hopefully, that serves as a benchmark for if the state government looks at a whole-of-Melbourne approach in terms of what should be implemented.” Loading Victoria Walks chief executive Sarah Pilgrim said the hire scheme should only be expanded if there were effective measures to keep scooters off footpaths, along with enforceable parking rules, better on-road riding infrastructure, national safety standards and no-fault insurance for injured third-parties. “When fast, heavy devices are introduced into [footpaths], even a small number of crashes can have very serious outcomes,” Pilgrim said. “When people don’t feel safe in public space, they walk less, and that has serious consequences for physical health, mental wellbeing and social connection.”

Advertisement

The injury data is based only on reports made to Lime and Neuron by riders or third parties, and could include false reports but also may not include injuries that were unreported. Lime and Neuron included the injury data in monthly reports to each council during the trial. Related Article Road safety Pedestrian fatalities reach 17-year-high. This trend could be why The Age lodged a freedom-of-information request to the City of Melbourne seeking those monthly reports in July 2024. The council agreed to provide the documents but Lime and Neuron took action in the Victorian Civil and Administrative Tribunal to prevent their release, arguing they contained sensitive commercial information. During mediation at VCAT, the two companies agreed to release a combined incident dataset. Transport Accident Commission data shows that across the same February 2022 to August 2024 period, there were 13 road deaths in the Melbourne, Yarra and Port Phillip council areas, all of which were pedestrians hit by vehicles.
